newsitem.title: USA: U.S. denies Latin jazz star Sandoval citizenship.
newsitem.headline: U.S. denies Latin jazz star Sandoval citizenship.

text.p: The United States has turned down a request for citizenship by Latin jazz trumpeter Arturo Sandoval, who defected from Cuba seven years ago, the musician said on Monday.
"I was really surprised and disappointed. It's a case of injustice," Sandoval said on Miami's Channel 7 news.

The Grammy-winning Sandoval, who has played at the White House and performed at this year's Oscar awards ceremony, said the Immigration and Naturalisation Service told him in a letter his citizenship request was denied because he had been a member of the Cuban Communist Party.
He said prominent musicians in Cuba were required to be party members, although he was not a communist.
"In my situation, I don't have any citizenship," said Sandoval, now a Miami resident.

Sandoval, who was championed by the late jazz great Dizzy Gillespie while still based in Cuba, defected in July 1990 when he ran into the U.S. Embassy in Rome while on a European tour. His first album after his defection was called "Flight to Freedom."
He said he would appeal the ruling.
